details.title: A Convolution Universal Generating Function Method for Evaluating the Symbolic One-to-All-Target-Subset Reliability Function of Acyclic Multi-State Information Networks

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Ind. Eng. & Eng. Manage., Nat. Tsing Hua Univ., Hsinchu, Taiwan

p: Wei-Chang Yeh (M'99–SM'09) is currently a professor of the Department of Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management at National Tsing Hua University in Taiwan. He received his M.S., and Ph.D. from the Department of Industrial Engineering at the University of Texas at Arlington. His research interests include network reliability theory, graph theory, deadlock problem, linear programming, and scheduling. He is a member of the IEEE, and INFORMS.

authors.name: Wei-Chang Yeh

details.abstract: The acyclic multi-state information network (AMIN) is an extension of the multi-state network without having to satisfy the flow conservation law. A very straightforward convolution universal generating function method (CUGFM) is developed to find the exact symbolic one-to-all-target-subset reliability function of AMIN. The correctness and computational complexity of the proposed algorithm will be proven. Two illustrative examples demonstrate the power of the proposed CUGFM to solve the exact symbolic reliability functions of the one-to-all-target-subset AMIN problem more efficiently than the best-known UGFM.

references.title: Multi-state system reliability. Assessment, optimization and applications

context.text: In recent years, the multi-state network problem has been applied extensively to many real-world systems such as oil/gas production systems [1], transportation systems [18], communication systems [2], distributed computing systems [3], [4], and power transmission systems [20].
MIN analysis has become an increasingly popular subject in network reliability [16]–[18].
In MIN, each node has different states determined by a set of nodes that receive the information directly without having to satisfy the conservation law [18], [19].
For example, computer networks or cellular telephone networks can be modeled as MIN [18], [20].

There are four different approaches to assess the reliability of AMIN [18]–[20]: the Universal Generating Function method (UGFM), the extension of the Boolean models to the multi-valued case, the Monte-Carlo simulation [13], and the stochastic process approach.

Since its initial introduction [16], the UGFM has proven to be very effective for evaluating the exact symbolic reliability of AMIN [16]–[18][24], and it does not demand rigorous computational effort.

references.text: A. Lisnianski, G. Levitin, "Multi-state system reliability. Assessment optimization and applications" in World Scientific, 2003.

In recent years, the multi-state network problem has been applied extensively to many real-world systems such as oil/gas production systems [1], transportation systems [18], communication systems [2], distributed computing systems [3], [4], and power transmission systems [20].
For example, computer networks or cellular telephone networks can be modeled as MIN [18], [20].

There are four different approaches to assess the reliability of AMIN [18]–[20]: the Universal Generating Function method (UGFM), the extension of the Boolean models to the multi-valued case, the Monte-Carlo simulation [13], and the stochastic process approach.
Compared with other methods, the UGFM involves intuitively simple, straightforward, and universal recursive procedures combined with simplification techniques [20].

Since its initial introduction [16], the UGFM has proven to be very effective for evaluating the exact symbolic reliability of AMIN [16]–[20][24], and it does not demand rigorous computational effort.

Further developments and applications of UGFM were presented in [20]–[24], and detailed description can be found in [20]–[25], which summarize the recent achievements in the field of network reliability estimation based on UGFM.
